message.content: We refer to the summary provided. The patient presented with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which are symptoms commonly associated with diverticulitis. The tenderness in the left lower quadrant also supports this diagnosis. Crohn's disease is associated with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. Cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and may be associated with nausea and vomiting, but not diarrhea. Irritable bowel syndrome usually presents with recurrent abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits, but not necessarily with fever and tenderness on physical exam.

Based on the patient’s symptoms and physical examination, the most likely diagnosis is diverticulitis. The patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. The 12-month history of intermittent constipation may suggest the presence of diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the colon. Diverticulitis occurs when these pouches become inflamed or infected, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Crohn disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and other gastrointestinal symptoms, but it is less likely given the acute onset of symptoms in this patient. Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder and can cause right upper quadrant abdominal pain, which is not present in this patient. Irritable bowel syndrome can cause abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits, but it is a diagnosis of exclusion and typically requires a more chronic history of symptoms.

We refer to the patient information provided. The patient’s abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea suggest gastrointestinal inflammation or infection. The tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant suggests the most likely diagnosis is diverticulitis. Crohn disease typically involves the ileum and causes diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Cholecystitis presents with right upper quadrant pain and nausea/vomiting after a high-fat meal. Irritable bowel syndrome does not typically cause fever or tenderness to palpation.

We refer to the patient information provided in the summary. The patient’s symptoms (abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea) along with the findings on physical examination (tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen) suggest the most likely diagnosis is diverticulitis. Crohn disease typically presents with diarrhea and pain in the right lower quadrant. Cholecystitis typically presents with pain in the right upper quadrant. Irritable bowel syndrome may present with abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits, but usually without fever or tenderness on exam.

We refer to the patient information provided. The patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Also, there is tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. These symptoms are consistent with diverticulitis, which is the inflammation or infection of diverticula (small pouches that develop in the lining of the digestive system). Crohn disease causes abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss but is usually associated with inflammation in the small intestine. Cholecystitis presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Irritable bowel syndrome presents with abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits but there is no tenderness or fever.

We refer to the given patient information. The patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, along with tenderness in the left lower quadrant. These symptoms suggest diverticulitis, which is inflammation of the diverticula in the colon. Crohn disease can present with abdominal pain but typically has diarrhea with blood and mucous, while cholecystitis usually presents with right upper quadrant pain and fever. Irritable bowel syndrome does not usually cause tenderness on examination.

We refer to the summary provided in the question stem to answer this question. The patient has a 12-hour history of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, with tenderness in the left lower quadrant on abdominal exam. She also has a history of intermittent constipation. These symptoms are suggestive of diverticulitis, which is inflammation of the diverticula in the colon. Crohn disease can also cause abdominal pain, but typically affects the small intestine rather than the colon. Cholecystitis typically presents with pain in the right upper quadrant, and irritable bowel syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of abdominal pain.

We refer to the information provided in the summary. The patient is presenting with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea which suggests a gastrointestinal issue. The tenderness in the left lower quadrant points towards diverticulitis, which is inflammation or infection of the pouches that form in the colon wall. Crohn disease would present with more diffuse abdominal pain and potentially bloody diarrhea. Cholecystitis would present with pain in the upper right quadrant and may have associated fever and jaundice. Irritable bowel syndrome may have similar symptoms but typically does not have fever or tenderness on exam.

We refer to the patient information and the options provided. The patient has abdominal pain that is constant and rated at 7/10, along with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which suggests an inflammatory process affecting the colon or lower intestine. The tenderness in the left lower quadrant indicates involvement of the sigmoid colon, consistent with diverticulitis. Crohn disease typically involves the terminal ileum or colon and can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Cholecystitis is usually associated with right upper quadrant pain and fever. Irritable bowel syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion and is characterized by recurrent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is diverticulitis.

We refer to the patient information provided. The patient has abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, along with a history of intermittent constipation. The tender spot in the left lower quadrant suggests that the most likely diagnosis is diverticulitis. Crohn disease would present with more diffuse abdominal pain and weight loss. Cholecystitis may present with right upper quadrant pain and fever. Irritable bowel syndrome does not typically cause fever, vomiting, or diarrhea with blood.
